abstract.p: Prof Ellen S Mankoff letter quotes from A E Housman's poem on pessimism (S)

In his poem beginning ''Terence, this is stupid stuff,'' A. E. Housman brilliantly expresses the power of negative thinking, or ''defensive pessimism'' (''Seeing Pessimism's Place in a Smiley-Faced World,'' Aug. 15):
Therefore, since the world has still
Much good, but much less good than ill,
And while the sun and moon endure
Luck's a chance, but trouble's sure,
I'd face it as a wise man would,
And train for ill and not for good.

Housman's speaker also argues for the health benefits of defensive pessimism: the poem ends with the example of Mithridates the king (notably, of ''the East'') who, knowing he was likely to be poisoned by his followers, sampled all the venoms of the earth to season himself against their ill effects: ''Mithridates, he died old.''
The writer is a professor of English at Kenyon College.
